admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation progress of the
            project was satisfactory overall. The execution of the road
            civil works, the strategic investment study, and the action
            plans for traffic safety and for air quality improvement
            separately rated as highly satisfactory while the progress
            of the transport efficiency action plan with the Land
            Transport Department was less satisfactory. The primary
            lesson emerging is of the importance of borrower ownership
            and the commitment of key officials to project design and
            implementation. Agencies will effectively perform given a
            clear mandate, appropriate institutional capacity, and
            timely technical and financial supports. Regulatory and
            institutional frameworks should be carefully assessed in
            light of the country policy objectives and in close
            coordination with key agencies before embarking on similar
            projects in order to minimize the overlap of
            responsibilities and conflicts of interest, especially where
            interagency communication is notoriously lacking. In
            practice, government procedures to allocate counterpart
            budget and national procurement regulations constitute a
            downside of the action plan and should be carefully
            addressed. Assigning an adequate number of qualified staff
            to the project is also a critical factor affecting the
            performance of agencies as is their technical capability to
            ensure quality of work. Therefore, allocate more budget to
            staff training. Finally more information should be
            disseminated about World Bank procedures and requisites.
